text:
Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online posts about where you are. The website's message was clear: when you say, "Hey, I'm at this place," you are telling everyone, including people you might not want to meet. This made people think about the problems with sharing too much online. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with the world, offering chances for wealth and fame. So, we share our secrets, photos, and stories online. But later, we might find out that this can be risky and confusing.

However, there is hope. A group of early internet users, called bloggers, learned these lessons before social media existed. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with fame. We can learn from their experiences. In 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started sharing his life online. He wrote about everything, and people were interested in his stories. But one day, he had to choose between his blog and his love life. He learned that sharing too much online can make people not trust you.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, who worked in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She wrote about her job, but someone at work shared her blog with her bosses, and she lost her job. This shows that what we say online can affect our real lives. Armstrong stopped blogging for a while but later started again, writing about her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger" and earns money from her writing. She learned that just because we can say anything online, it doesn't mean we should.

Some time ago, scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe we don't understand. Scientists usually agree with this idea because no one knows everything about the universe. However, some scientists were worried about the film and called it "atrocious" and "dangerous." This made people curious to watch it.

At first, the film seemed harmless. Scientists talked about how new discoveries show the universe is stranger than we thought. But then the film talked about discoveries like water molecules being changed by thoughts. A Japanese researcher claimed that the shape of a water molecule could change just by the thoughts of people around it. The film showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by happy people and looking bad after being exposed to someone in a bad mood. Some people found this evidence convincing, but many scientists did not.

The idea that water is affected by thoughts is amazing and could mean new forces are at work in the universe. But we need strong proof to believe it, and pictures of crystals are not enough. The real problem is that the film's claims were not strange enough. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is expanding because of a mysterious force called "dark energy." These discoveries are based on years of research.

Other amazing discoveries are also being made. Neuroscientists found that our brain takes about half a second to process what we see, but we don't notice this delay. Anthropologists think they know where modern humans first lived and why they moved to other places. Some theorists believe there are links between life on Earth and the design of the universe.

Science is not finished. We are still far from knowing everything. New ideas like chaos and quantum uncertainty show that we can't understand everything completely. Scientists are trying to create a "Theory of Everything" to explain all the forces and particles in the universe. Many people think the universe is best described with one word: incredible.

I find writing novels difficult, but writing short stories is fun. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, and writing a short story is like planting a garden. Both are important to me. The trees in the forest give shade, and the wind moves the leaves. In the garden, flowers bloom, and bees and butterflies come. This shows how seasons change. 

Since I started writing, I switch between novels and short stories. After finishing a novel, I want to write short stories. After finishing short stories, I want to write a novel. I never write both at the same time because they use different parts of my brain. 

I started with two short novels in 1975. Then, from 1984 to 1985, I began writing short stories. It was hard at first, but I enjoyed it. My world of stories grew bigger, and readers liked this new side of me. One of my first stories, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story book, Tales from Abroad. 

Writing short stories is nice because they don’t take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to make a short story good, but I can keep changing it. Writing a novel takes a year or two and is much harder. Short stories are a nice break for me. 

You can make a short story from a small idea, a word, or an image. It’s like jazz music, where the story goes where it wants. If a story doesn’t work, it’s okay. Not every story is great, even for famous writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. I learn from my mistakes and use them in my next story. 

When I write novels, I learn from my short stories. Short stories are like a test place for me. Without them, writing novels would be harder. My short stories are like soft shadows or small footprints I leave behind. I remember each one and how I felt when I wrote it. They are like signs to my heart, and I am happy to share these feelings with my readers.

Science is a big part of our lives. It can be very abstract, like philosophy, or very practical, like curing diseases. Science has made our lives easier, but it can also be dangerous. It tries to understand everything from tiny ants to the huge universe. Science is important, but sometimes people misunderstand it or think it is perfect when it is not.

Science is always changing. New ideas often replace old ones, even if people first laugh at them. Scientists sometimes feel jealous or angry, but their work is important. This book talks about big ideas in science that changed how we think. We will look at these ideas and see their beauty, but also remember that science has limits.

Science is not always right. Scientists often find new explanations that change what we know. Sometimes these changes are small, but sometimes they are big and change our beliefs. For example, in the 17th century, people thought the universe was like a big clock. Later, scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein showed us new ways to understand the universe.

Science keeps moving forward. At the end of the 19th century, people thought there was nothing new to discover in physics. But then we found radioactivity, X-rays, and many other things. Now, some people think we might soon understand everything about the universe. Maybe this is true, maybe not.

Science is powerful. In the last 200 years, we have learned not just to watch nature but to change it. Sometimes we change things without understanding the effects. Science needs to be watched carefully. Everyone should know about science because it affects our future and the world our children will live in. Science is not just for scientists; it is important for everyone.

Starting around 2015, big publishers noticed that ebook sales stopped growing or even went down. This made people question if ebooks would be important in the future. One publishing executive said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments, and his company lost faith in traditional books. Even though digital and print books can exist together, people still wonder if ebooks will replace print books. This idea makes us think and talk a lot. Why do we see ebooks and print books as fighting each other? This question is about more than just books; it shows how we feel about new things and changes. 

In my research, I found that people often think new technology will replace old ones. For example, when TV was invented, people thought radio would disappear, but radio survived by being used in cars and other places. The idea of books disappearing is not new. In 1894, people thought phonographs would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This has happened many times with movies, radio, TV, and smartphones. Some people thought losing books would be bad for culture, while others thought ebooks were much better. 

When new technology comes, like e-readers, it changes how we feel about things we use every day. We often feel close to things like books, TVs, and computers. So, when new technology appears, we miss the old things. This is why people still like old products and technologies. For example, when the printing press spread in Europe, people wanted original manuscripts. When movies got sound, people missed silent films. The same happened with photography and music records. E-readers made people appreciate the feel and smell of old books. 

This should comfort those worried about print books disappearing. But the idea of losing old media will always be interesting because it shows how technology changes us and how we resist change. We use stories to understand change, like stories of endings. The story of books disappearing shows our excitement for the future and our fear of losing what we know and love.

For a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30 every weekday. I brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how famous people from the past 400 years did their best work. I wanted to know how they found time each day to be creative and productive. I looked at their daily lives, like when they slept, ate, and worked, to understand their habits and personalities.

The book I wrote is called "Daily Rituals." It talks about people's routines, which are the things they do every day. Routines can help us use our time and energy better. The psychologist William James said that having good habits can help us focus on important things. But he also had trouble sticking to a schedule.

I got the idea for this book one Sunday when I was supposed to be working on a story for a magazine. Instead, I was cleaning my desk and making coffee. I am a morning person, so I work best in the early hours. That day, I started looking online for how other writers worked. I found many interesting stories and decided to collect them in a blog called "Daily Routines." This blog later became the book.

In the book, I included many different people's routines. I used quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. I also used information from biographies and articles. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section for anyone who wants to read more.

Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His father decided they could not go on holiday to Spain because of money problems. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, Howard found an ammonite* on the beach. This made him want to become a palaeontologist. 

At university, Howard decided he wanted to study the very old times, not dinosaurs. He liked studying small, ancient creatures in rocks. After finishing his studies, he worried about finding a job. He knew he was good, but getting a job was not always fair. 

When a job at Tavistock College in London was available, he applied. On the day of his interview, the professor who liked another candidate could not come. Another professor, who did not like the first professor, helped Howard get the job. Howard was happy to get the job, even though he later learned why he got it. 

Howard liked his job because he could plan his work. But life was not always easy. One day, someone stole his briefcase with important notes. He had to cancel a lecture. While having coffee, he met a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. He learned about a new collection of fossils there. This was a big opportunity for him. 

Because of the theft, Howard changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students to Scotland. Instead, he wanted to go to Nairobi to study the fossils. 

*An ammonite is a type of fossil.

Charles Spence is a professor at Oxford University in the UK. He studies how our senses work together to create the taste of food. At home, he even has ice cream made from bee larvae, which tastes a bit like nuts and flowers. Spence and his team are trying to make eating bugs more normal. They study how different things, like who we eat with or the color of our plates, change how food tastes. 

Spence wrote a book called "The Perfect Meal" with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman. It has many interesting facts about eating. For example, the first person to order food in a restaurant usually enjoys their meal the most. Also, we eat more when we are with other people.

Spence's lab in Oxford is simple, with old equipment. This helps him work with chefs who can't pay for research. His work is often paid for by big food companies. These companies want to reduce salt and sugar in their products without people noticing. They do it slowly so customers don't taste the change.

Spence also works with famous chefs like Heston Blumenthal. Together, they created a dish called "Sound of the Sea" that uses sound to change how food tastes. Spence found that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, while low-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. Some airlines and food brands are using his research to match music with food.

At home, Spence has fun dinner parties. Once, they ate rabbit with fur on the cutlery. Another time, they used colored lights and sounds to see how it changed the taste of drinks. For Spence, home and work are closely connected.

Our brains are working harder than ever before. We get a lot of information, some true and some not, and we have to decide what is important and what we can ignore. We are also doing more things by ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents booked our flights, and salespeople helped us in shops. Now, we do these things on our own. We try to manage our lives, families, jobs, hobbies, and TV shows, and our smartphones help us do this. But there is a problem. We think we are doing many things at once, but this is not true. Earl Miller, a scientist at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching quickly between tasks, which is not efficient. Multitasking can make us stressed and confused. It makes our brains want more new things to focus on, which distracts us. The part of the brain that helps us focus is easily distracted by new things. Just having the chance to multitask can make us perform worse. Glenn Wilson, a psychology professor, found that trying to focus on a task while having an unread email can lower our IQ by almost 10 points. Multitasking can be worse than being tired. Russ Poldrack, a scientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework and watch TV at the same time, the information goes to a part of the brain that stores skills, not facts. Without TV, the information goes to a part of the brain that organizes it better. Multitasking also involves making decisions, like whether to answer a text or not. Making many small decisions can make us tired and lead to bad decisions. Many people, like business leaders and scientists, say email is a big problem. It is not the email itself, but the large amount of communication. A colleague's son said his father just answers emails all day, which is almost true. We feel we must reply to emails, but it is hard to do that and finish other tasks.

In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino broke concrete into pieces at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people did not think these questions were important. Scientists studied animal behavior and the results, but they did not think animals had feelings or thoughts. Recently, this has changed a bit. Research on animals like bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens shows that animals might have emotions. This idea is now in some popular science books, like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". This has started a debate: do animals have consciousness? This leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong? In an experiment with cows, those that opened a gate to get food were happier than those that had help. If cows like solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? Some people, like Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, think we should stop eating meat. He believes this is a big change in how we think about ethics, like when slavery ended. Aubrey Manning, a professor, thinks we should rethink how we see animal intelligence. He says animals have a simpler way of thinking than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop giving animals human traits. These experts may never agree because the main issue is philosophical, not just scientific or moral. It is hard to define consciousness, so can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe talks about an experiment with starlings, a type of bird, that he thinks shows they can feel depressed. At Newcastle University, starlings were put in two groups. One group had nice cages, and the other had small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid bad worms from another. Later, when only bad worms were offered, only the birds in nice cages ate them. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt pessimistic. Balcombe, who works with animal rights groups, believes we will one day see animals like we see racism now. He says we cannot support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger. If he was the only one with this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning agrees with him. Manning wrote a book about animal behavior. He says ideas about animals change over time. In the early 1900s, people thought animals thought like humans, but then they changed their minds. Now, the idea is changing again. It is a difficult topic, and people have strong opinions.

Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or hear better. Adrian West, a research director, says that people think arguments help find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might also change how we solve problems and make it harder to think deeply. We see a lot of poor thinking and opinions, which can confuse us. More data does not always mean more knowledge or better decisions. Reading books has decreased, and some people, like Patricia Greenfield, think this affects critical thinking. She says we focus more on quick media and doing many things at once instead of concentrating on one thing. We don't know exactly how technology affects thinking, but it changes how we think. Computers and the internet can be good or bad for thinking, depending on how we use them. Reading helps us think and imagine, but visual media like video games and TV do not. However, visual media can improve some skills. Many young people do not use their full potential because of this. How we see technology affects how we think about critical thinking. Video games are often seen as bad for kids, but James Paul Gee says they can be good for learning. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and thinking skills. In the digital age, as reading and math scores go down, we need to understand how technology affects thinking.

Matthew Crawford is a writer and a motorcycle mechanic. He used to work in an office but did not like it. He wrote a book about how working with your hands is good. His new book talks about how to live in the modern world. He got the idea when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. He thinks these ads make it hard for us to focus on what we want to think about. 

Crawford says that because of these distractions, we find it hard to think or remember things. We also avoid talking to strangers because we don't want to be interrupted. He believes that things like video games and phone apps take over our attention. Many people feel the same way. For example, some people complain about emails but still check them all the time. Studies show that just seeing a phone on the table can distract us.

Crawford thinks technology makes us focus too much on ourselves. We often choose to send a text instead of talking to a friend. This can make us lose real connections with people. He gives an example of a gym where people used to share music, but now everyone listens to their own music with earphones. This change makes the gym less social.

Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we should have rules to reduce noise and distractions in public places. Second, we should do activities that make us focus on real things, like cooking or playing sports. These activities help us connect with the world and other people. They also help us pay better attention to what is important.

Text: "‘What do you do for a living?’ is a common question. We often talk about our jobs. But when you are a philosopher, like me, it is a bit harder to answer. Saying you are a philosopher can sound like you think you are special or know more than others. This is not true; philosophers are just like everyone else. But people often think philosophers are different. 

One reason is that philosophers think about life and ideas. A long time ago, a Greek philosopher named Aristotle said that thinking about life is the best way to live. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that we should think about our lives and not just follow what everyone else does. This helps us make our own choices. 

Thinking about life does not mean you have to read many books or think deeply all the time. It means looking at your daily life and making sure it is good for you. It is practical and should be shared with others because it helps us live better lives.

Another reason people think philosophers are different is that academic philosophy has become very specialized. Philosophers often write for other experts, not for everyone. This makes it hard for people to understand what philosophers do. 

I sometimes call myself an ‘ethicist’ because I study ethics, which is about deciding if actions are right or wrong. But ethics is more than just following rules. It also looks at how we think about responsibility and our attitudes. Philosophy helps us look closely at our actions and beliefs. By doing this, we can learn more about ourselves and help everyone."

Text: People who love food, like foodies, chefs, and gourmands, think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. In the past, philosophers talked about food to explain other ideas, like learning. Sometimes, they seemed to talk about food, but they were really discussing other things. 

An interesting example is the Greek philosopher Epicurus. He talked about enjoying life and avoiding pain in many ways. But today, people think of him as someone who loved eating and drinking. His name is used in restaurant names and food websites because it makes them sound special.

Food is very social and cultural. It comes from history and is shared with people around us. We eat with others and get our food from farms and stores. We deal with food more than any other thing, so it is a good topic to think about deeply.

When food is ready, people talk and write about it. Some say food critics are not special; they just describe food well. Most studies on how we sense things focus on sight, not taste, and this should change.

Food also has an artistic side. We say paintings and music are beautiful, but not food. Some think food should be part of art discussions, like sculpture or poetry. But food is eaten and gone, unlike art that lasts, so some say food cannot be true art.

There are many ethical questions about food. What should we eat: organic, free-range, local, vegetarian, or non-GMO? Our choices show our beliefs, and philosophers ask why we choose what we do.

Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a duty to their guests because of love and friendship. Everyone is welcome in a home kitchen. Professional cooks have duties to their boss and the food, so only trained people work in their kitchens.

A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ talks about how food can help connect different cultures. We can learn about others by enjoying their food and eating together, which has been important in international relations. The essay uses fun stories to explain this idea to readers.

Rob Daviau, from the US, makes special board games called 'legacy' games. He thought the board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. So, he wondered if board games could change. Could they have a story? Could choices in one game affect the next game? He changed a classic game called Risk to make Risk Legacy. In this game, choices you make can change the game forever. You might have to tear up cards or change the board. The game is played over several sessions, and players remember past actions. Daviau said, ‘You can point to the board and say: “You did this!”’

Daviau also helped make a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players work together to stop diseases. His next game was SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was very popular, SeaFall was a big test for legacy games because it was a new idea. In SeaFall, set in the age of sail (16th – mid 19th century), players explore new lands. Legacy game designers must think about all player choices to keep the story together. They use testers to see how the game works. Jaime Barriga, a tester for SeaFall, said it takes a lot of time. Sometimes the game works well at first, but then it breaks, and they have to fix it.

Legacy games were not expected to be very popular. Daviau thought only a few people would like them. He said, ‘I thought I would be known as the guy who did this weird project.’ But many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He thinks it is a big change in game design. ‘It’s exciting to learn a new game or way to play,’ he said. Ben Hogg, another fan, liked the adventure in legacy games. He said, ‘You’re buying into an experience. It’s like the stories in video games.’

The legacy format is like video games and TV shows with episodes. Daviau wanted to write for TV but ended up in game design. He likes telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock says making a legacy game is like writing a book. ‘You need to know how it starts and ends,’ he said. Daviau is happy to see others use his idea but thinks people will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, from the publisher of SeaFall, thinks legacy games change how we see board games.

One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and went into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online and seemed like something from a children's movie. People enjoy stories like this because they like to think animals are like humans. Octopuses are very smart, even though they look very different from us. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells for protection, and even play in a smart way.

Some people think it's not scientific to say animals are like humans. But Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, says it's wrong to ignore the human-like traits of animals. He calls this "anthropodenial." He says animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding others' motives. Animals are smarter than we often think.

In the past, people thought animals were smart enough to be put on trial for crimes. Charles Darwin, who created the theory of evolution, said the difference between humans and animals is not big. In the 20th century, people started to see animals as machines that just respond to things. They thought animals didn't have feelings or thoughts. This view came at a time when humans were destroying animal habitats and not caring for animal welfare.

Now, de Waal believes we are starting to understand animal intelligence better. He says we are learning a lot about animals, thanks to the internet. The best tests for animal intelligence consider what each animal is good at. For example, squirrels are great at remembering where they hide nuts, even if they might not do well on human memory tests.

In her book, "The Soul of an Octopus," naturalist Sy Montgomery says if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might ask how many color patterns we can make on our skin. We would fail that test, and the octopus might think we are not smart.

De Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean. But he knows that stories like Inky's help people appreciate how smart animals are. He once did an experiment with capuchin monkeys to see if they feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the ones with cucumbers got upset because grapes are better. A video of this experiment convinced many people that animals can feel envy. This shows how powerful stories and videos can be in changing our minds about animals.

Robots were once just in science fiction stories, but now they are becoming very important in our world. They are changing how we work, just like machines did during the industrial revolution. For many years, robots have been used in car factories and other industries. Now, experts say robots will soon be used in many more areas, and many countries are not ready for this big change.

Most people think robots will do most of the work humans do in the next 50 years. But, many also believe their own jobs will still be around. This is not true. Robots will change every job sector in the next few years. For example, an Australian company made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This is much faster than two people can do in a day. In San Francisco, a robot named Tally helps in supermarkets by checking if products are on the shelves and priced correctly.

People who support robots say they will create new jobs for people who can fix and program them. But, some people worry that robots will take away the need for human skills. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots will change jobs. He says that soon, robots will be smarter and work well with humans. Many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and governments will make new rules about robots.

In five years, salaries in the robotics field will go up, but many jobs will not be filled because there are not enough skilled workers. Dr. Zhang says people need to learn new skills to keep up with technology. We cannot expect to do the same job forever.

New robots will also be made for homes and personal use. These robots will be more advanced and interact with us in new ways. This is a big chance for companies, but it also means we need new rules to keep us safe. With many jobs at risk, education is important to prepare for the future. Countries need more people studying science, technology, engineering, and maths (STEM) to stay competitive.

Text: George Mallory, a famous mountain climber, once said he wanted to climb Mount Everest "because it’s there." People often wonder why anyone would do something so dangerous. Mallory's answer might inspire some people to follow their dreams. It shows that climbing can be about adventure and fun. 

In 1967, a writer named Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay about climbing. He said there are seven different types of climbing, each with its own rules. For example, some climbs use a lot of equipment, while others use very little. This idea has become very popular among climbers.

Many climbers love the feeling of freedom they get from climbing. But climbing can also be difficult and limiting, like when a storm keeps you stuck in a tent. This is a bit of a puzzle, but some say that having fewer choices makes life simpler and more free.

Joe Fitschen, a rock climber, thinks we should ask "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is in our genes. We like to take on challenges and test our limits, even if it's risky. This might be more about our biology than about thinking it through.

Brian Treanor, a US academic, says climbing can help us develop important qualities like courage and respect for nature. He thinks these are important in today's world, where people often avoid risks.

Some climbers believe that climbing without help from others or technology is more challenging and deserves more recognition. Ebert and Robinson, two expert climbers, said that climbing alone or without extra help is harder and should be respected more. But this idea can be dangerous if it encourages people to take unnecessary risks.

Climbing can also be about being in the moment and focusing on the task. Some people say climbing is like Zen philosophy, which helps train the mind to find peace. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

Alfred Brendel was a famous pianist for over 60 years. He was very serious and focused on playing European piano music. He wrote and played a lot but did not teach much. People who knew him well saw he could be fun, but he was serious during concerts. He spent a lot of time studying, traveling, and performing.

A few years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not want to teach him because he had not taught many students before. He thought it was like asking a mountain guide to teach a child to walk. But Kit, who was about 14, played the piano very well. Brendel listened to him and was impressed. Kit played beautifully, and Brendel decided to teach him.

Now, Kit is 19 and is becoming known in the music world. Brendel is careful to make sure Kit does not get too tired or stressed. Kit is very active and likes to learn new things, like languages and math. He also writes music and plays tennis, with his mother always watching over him.

Brendel says it is important to write music to understand it better. Kit has a great memory and can read music very well. He listens carefully to Brendel and can do what he is told. Brendel is careful not to say Kit will be a great pianist too soon because it can be harmful if people expect too much.

Brendel is now 80 years old and does not perform anymore. He says he did not want to be famous quickly but wanted to achieve certain things by the age of 50. He feels he has done many of those things and is happy with his life now, even though he does not play the piano anymore.

When I was a child, I thought gardens were always beautiful places. My Grandad’s garden was not in a dirty city. It was next to a river and went down gently to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and birds singing in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – a place to escape and find peace. Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old windows, with plastic covering broken glass.

At home, my father was often quiet. He wasn’t boring, though. He liked funny things and had favorite phrases like ‘It’s immaterial to me,’ which means ‘I don’t mind.’ He probably wished he had done more with his life. He left school without finishing and learned to be a plumber. He didn’t love plumbing; it was just his job. He wasn’t very ambitious, but once he and Mum thought about moving to Canada, but it didn’t happen. He was good at fixing things at home, like making bookshelves or cupboards.

My parents moved house only once. But my mother liked to change furniture often. The biggest change was when we got a piano. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mother thought they were too fancy and took them away. I never got to play the piano. My sister had lessons instead. When I asked my mother why I didn’t get lessons, she said, ‘You’d never have practised.’

I liked going to the river. I could imagine being in another world. I would take a fishing net and wear old sandals. I’d walk along the river, find a spot, take off my sandals, and look for fish to catch with my net. After trying to keep them alive at home, I put them back in the river.

I wanted to leave school as soon as I could, but it didn’t seem possible. Then one day, my father said, ‘There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might like it.’ My dad usually didn’t like gardening, but he saw that I loved it. I think he hoped it would be good for me. Even if he didn’t like gardening, he saw my passion for it.

Lawrence MacEwen is on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I am with him. The strong wind from the Atlantic Ocean is very powerful. It feels like it could blow us off the cliff and into the ocean below. Lawrence's sheepdog, Tie, comes to us, and Lawrence pets him gently. The wind is loud, but Lawrence is comfortable here on his island. He is showing me around. He points to the north and shouts, ‘That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.’ I see rain falling on Rum's big mountains. ‘Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay,’ he says. Suddenly, Lawrence says he needs to move his sheep because rain is coming. We walk down the hill, and he tells me about the island. Muck is three kilometers long and half as wide. The geese eat a lot of grass. The MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. We stop talking to move the sheep. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to gather the sheep but is not doing well. Lawrence tells Tie to go to the right, but Tie goes straight, causing confusion. Lawrence is disappointed and says, ‘That will never do.’ The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm. Their son, Colin, manages the cottages, and their daughter, Mary, runs the island hotel with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby like that their two boys can explore the island and sail boats in the summer. ‘They go out and come back when they’re hungry,’ Mary says. But living on the island has challenges. Electricity is only available sometimes. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to come on. The next morning, Mary makes breakfast using a flashlight. I get used to it, even without mobile phone service. Mary tells me, ‘There is mobile reception on the hill. Most people last a couple of days, then put the phone away.’ So I do the same. Life on Muck is surprising. Today, a boat brings groceries and three musicians. They play music in the island’s tearoom, and everyone enjoys it. That night, by the fire, Lawrence tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. Her father bought a farm on the Isle of Soay without seeing it. Jenny was sent to manage it, even though she only had typing skills. I go to bed with the sound of rain and wake up to more rain. I eat well because almost all the food comes from the island. Mary sends me to get fresh fish from Sandy Mathers, a fisherman. I bring it back to Mary, and by 7 pm, we have a delicious fish dinner. The next morning, I am supposed to take a ferry to another island. But many ferries have been canceled because of high waves. If my ferry doesn’t come, I will stay on Muck for two more days. Secretly, I hope to stay longer, even without a phone.

The game design industry used to be mostly for computer scientists and people who taught themselves. It was often seen as just a hobby for young people. But now, the video games industry is taken seriously. Making video games is not easy. When a new movie comes out, video games based on it need many team members and months of hard work. Like many industries, it is hard to get into, but it is growing.

Jim Donelly, who works for an online games magazine, says it is hard to make progress in big companies or to have a say in big games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever. Not just the people who lead the whole game, but also those who design parts of it. How can you enter this competitive industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim thinks differently. He says the only way is to make games. You need to create something to get a job. Game design is more than a job; it is a way of life. Like any creative work, you have to do it to make it real.

Another expert, John Field, says there are other ways. Many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s needs. Even fewer have the creative talent, technical skills, vision, and business ability to help the industry grow. Can you do it alone? John says it is tricky, but a good course in games can help. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all kinds of entertainment and arts. They might have worked for a few years after finishing school and then decided that games are their passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and know how diverse games can be. Connections can also help. To succeed in games, you need to network.

The idea of a young boy always playing games is outdated. Now, games are seen as a grown-up activity. Families play together on interactive consoles. Smartphones have many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of room for growth. Games are popular with large audiences and are a great way to learn. He sees many new possibilities and opportunities in this big area.

Since I was a child, I always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he didn't force me. I had a friend whose dad was very pushy. He always told my friend what he couldn't do. My friend stopped wanting to play football because of this. I am happy my dad was not like that. 

When I score a great goal from far away, people say it's just luck, but it's not. I have practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. You need to practice a lot to score amazing goals. The best players in the world practice for many years, even if they have natural talent. 

Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I learned technique. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning skills. At school, I played many sports like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know education is important, but back then, I only thought about football. The teachers did a good job, but I didn't notice it at the time. I don't want it to be like that for my son. We try to read him books, but he is too young to sit still. He likes to kick the books around, like me.

At the start of my professional football career, the manager helped young players like me join the first team. He didn't make a big deal about it, but we knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A TV presenter said, "You can't win anything with kids." This made us realize we had a lot to do. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team.

I rely on my close friends and family a lot. Having a lot of money can cause problems. People say, "I can't believe you let your mother keep working." I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and they would not like to be on my payroll. My mum is a hairdresser and loves her job. I like to use my money to help people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think. Money doesn't solve everything.

After I stop playing football, I want to take a year off to do things I couldn't do before. I want to go skiing right after I stop playing. I can't ski now because if I break a leg, I can't play football, and I wouldn't be insured.

Sam Carter helped us find a place to live at Reef Point. Sam was my dad's agent in Los Angeles. My dad couldn't write anything good in Los Angeles, so Sam found us a cheap place to live. Reef Point was quiet in the summer because the sun was often hidden by sea fogs. Not many people visited because the road was not nice, and a nicer place, La Carmella, was nearby. Only people with little money or those who loved surfing came to Reef Point. But when the weather got hot, many people came, and it became busy. My dad was busy writing a script and was in a bad mood. I spent most days on the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. We didn't have a dog when we moved to Reef Point, but Rusty decided to stay with us. I gave him water, and my dad pretended to be angry but wasn't really. Rusty loved the beach and often brought me things he found, like shoes or towels, which I had to return to their owners. He also liked to swim with me, even though I was faster. One day, after swimming, we watched surfers. One surfer was very good and came to talk to me. She asked why I didn't surf, and I said I didn't have a board or money. She realized I was British and asked about my dad. When I said his name, Rufus Marsh, she recognized his book, "Tall as the Morning," and became more interested in talking to me.

Violet Hetherington was in a long line at the dock in Southampton. She was waiting to get on the ship called the Queen Caroline. Her friend Annie had told her to arrive late to avoid waiting, but this advice was wrong. An announcement said there was a problem with the computer system, and the passengers were getting upset. They had paid a lot of money for this trip and wanted it to be special. Violet felt like leaving. She looked for her phone in her bag but couldn't find it. This made her feel even worse about the trip. She couldn't call the taxi company to check if she left her phone there because all her numbers were in the phone. Her son Harry always told her to be careful about this. 

Violet asked a friendly couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message asking him to ask her neighbor Kristina to check if the phone was at home. If it wasn't there, she would have trouble finding the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her was relieved, but she didn't tell Harry. Harry thought he was wiser than his mother. Her younger son, Daniel, was more understanding because he was forgetful too. 

Finally, the line started moving, and Violet gave her travel documents to go on the ship. She felt disappointed when she saw the ship's foyer. It looked like a hotel trying too hard to be fancy, with fake wood, shiny chandeliers, and airport-style carpets. She followed signs to the elevators, which were full of tired passengers. Violet was squished in the elevator until she reached the twelfth floor. She was happy to find her room had the balcony she wanted. She had paid extra to make sure she could see the sea, ignoring Annie's advice to wait for a last-minute deal.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he didn't know he was starting a journey into the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof wanted pictures for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 photos by Maier, a street photographer who took amazing pictures. Now, Maloof has a big collection of Maier’s work. In his home, he has her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, 100,000 negatives, and many 8mm movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked at all of it and realized he found something special by accident. ‘When I bought this, I didn’t know what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I could have sold it all to someone else.’ Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon are learning about Maier’s life. They talked to families she worked for as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she went back to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person and always had a camera with her. She wore big coats, wide hats, and strong shoes. ‘On her day off, she would leave with her camera and come back late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier to care for his daughter. ‘She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. She wasn’t very social, but she liked to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, sometimes recording them on audiotape. She loved taking pictures of the world around her. ‘She was a true artist and did what she wanted,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anything stop her.’ Maier’s work was pure art; she didn’t do it for money. Her photos often show women, children, old people, and the poor. ‘Vivian’s pictures are very interesting,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees the influence of other photographers in her work and wonders if she created her own style. ‘Was Vivian very skilled or did she copy others?’ Maloof wonders if he will ever look at all the negatives, which he keeps in three big, fireproof cabinets. The funny thing is, he wasn’t interested in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. ‘As I learned more about photography and looked at her work again, I saw that people and street scenes were important to her,’ he said. ‘There was more to her work than I thought. Now, we want to make her famous. We want Vivian Maier to be in history books.’

When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But this is not true for Eleanor Catton's book, The Luminaries. I talked to her in the UK when her book was very popular. She was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She told me a funny story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her book, and the officer asked, "What's it about?" This is a hard question for a writer. 

The Luminaries is set in New Zealand in the 1860s. There are some crimes, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story becomes very complicated. Catton wanted to write a murder mystery, not a history book, but she found the past made the story more interesting. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention. When I asked her how it feels to be successful at a young age, she said it feels nice because people in her small country feel proud of her success. She also said it is annoying when people think her book is not serious. 

Catton had an idea to write the book like a spiral, with each part half the length of the one before. The book gets faster as it goes. I asked if it matters if readers notice this. She said she wanted to make a book with patterns that don't matter, but if you care, you can see them. Even with its unusual structure, The Luminaries is an exciting murder mystery. Surprisingly, she didn't plan the whole story before writing. She liked to write herself into difficult situations and then find a way out. She also wanted the book to be fun for readers. 

We talked about her love for TV drama series. The Luminaries has cliff-hangers, different viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would like to write for TV. She said, "That could be pretty cool." She was very enthusiastic and laughed often. She loves talking about her work and New Zealand. She notices how her imagination changes when she is in different places. She understands why writers leave New Zealand for busy cities. But for now, she will stay in New Zealand. Many people hope it inspires her to write more books.

Jonny Kinkead loved making things and playing the guitar when he was a boy. For the last forty years, he has been building guitars by hand. He says, "I still love the guitar. It's amazing how two pieces of wood can make a beautiful sound. Using different types of wood makes different sounds, and that still amazes me."

Jonny learned to play his brother's guitar at age eleven. At sixteen, he wanted a bass guitar. Instead of buying one, he decided to make it himself. He studied guitars to understand how different shapes and woods change the sound. The bass guitar was the first instrument he made from scratch, but he and his brothers had already been making model boats and planes. His father taught them how to use tools.

Jonny's bass guitar was good, but he didn't think about making guitars as a job. He liked painting and sculpture too. After school, he studied architecture at university because he liked design. But he left the course halfway through because he wanted to do something more creative. He realized that making guitars is like sculpture because it involves shaping sound. He thought it was a practical way to make art because people use guitars.

Jonny has been making guitars for a living ever since. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows to earn money. At first, he sold guitars for just the cost of the materials. As he became known as a good guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, he only makes about ten guitars a year, which limits his earnings.

In the beginning, Jonny worked hard to get noticed. He went to music festivals and asked musicians to try his guitars and tell others about him. He also learned how to price his guitars, which was difficult for him.

Jonny thinks it's easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. When he started, people thought only American guitars were good. But now, UK-made guitars are respected. Jonny says new guitar-makers should take courses to learn important skills. However, he believes learning by trying different things is also important. He says, "Look at other instruments, see what works or doesn't, and try new things. If you learn from someone else, you only learn one way. If you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything."

When English people talk, they often start by talking about the weather. This is a tradition. A famous writer from the 18th century, Dr. Johnson, said that when two English people meet, they first talk about the weather. This is still true today. Many people think English people talk about the weather because they are very interested in it. But this is not true. 

Some writers, like Bill Bryson, say the English weather is not exciting. There are no big storms or dangerous weather like in other places. Another writer, Jeremy Paxman, says the English weather is interesting because it is always changing. You never know what the weather will be like.

However, the real reason English people talk about the weather is different. Talking about the weather is a way for English people to start a conversation. It helps them talk to each other. When someone says, "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" they are not really asking about the weather. These are just ways to say hello or start talking.

There are three main times when English people talk about the weather: 
1. As a greeting.
2. To start a conversation.
3. When there is nothing else to talk about.

Because of this, it seems like English people talk about the weather a lot. But really, they use it to help them talk to each other.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to tell her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip instead of going to Spain, Greece, or France. They wanted to know why the wall was built, but Alice felt her answers were not good enough. She couldn't find a good historical novel to help explain life at the Wall in Roman times, so she decided to write one herself. 

After teaching for 31 years, Alice retired and started writing in 2001. She felt it was a big change. Teaching was like acting, with a performance every day, and it was very tiring. Writing was exciting but not as exhausting. Her old teaching friends were jealous because she still connected with children through her books. Alice wanted her books to fill a gap in children's fiction. She thought many books for teenagers were about negative experiences or total fantasy like Harry Potter. Her books were different.

Alice liked to teach English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel Tale of Troy. She loved seeing children go from being bored to interested and from not understanding to understanding. She saw her writing as a way to keep teaching. She started writing her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. She didn’t want to spend her summer on a course she thought she didn’t need.

Before the course, she had to send her best piece of fiction. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. After three hours and 30 pages, she sent it and was accepted. During the course, other students liked her story and suggested she publish it. With only school report cards as proof of her writing, she asked for a year off to write her first novel. Her husband, Zachary Leader, who is a critic and editor, helped her a lot. He read her chapters, changed sentences, and suggested new words. Alice’s mother-in-law thought they were rival authors, but Alice felt they worked well together.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. The race was between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny would drive a car on the roads, and his younger brother Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 

Jonny was excited about the race. He said, "I’ve never done anything like this before. It’s exciting! The roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold now, so I’ll be warm in the car." Alistair was also excited. He wore full winter cycling clothes, while Jonny wore jeans and a sweatshirt. Alistair joked, "I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway up."

The race started at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and ended at Fleet Moss, the highest road in Yorkshire, 350 meters up. The car might have an easy time, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill at the start. After a quick handshake, the race began. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside, while Jonny drove on the road. They would see each other again at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?

Jonny’s confidence dropped quickly. Just 15 seconds into the drive, a big tractor blocked the road. "Welcome to Yorkshire," he said to the cameraman in his car. "If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!" After the tractor moved, Jonny continued driving. Alistair struggled with the steep hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched him as he walked with the bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top. The ground was open, and the sun came out. Alistair started to go faster.

In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The roads in Yorkshire are very old and narrow. Jonny had to drive slowly around tight corners and through a stream on the road. After the last village, the road was straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. Jonny sped towards Fleet Moss, while Alistair rode across his last field and onto the road from the other side. Alistair reached the finish line first. He asked the crowd, "Is he here?" When they said no, he raised his arms and said, "Yes!" A few minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car. "Well done," Jonny said sadly. "I’m disappointed."

Text: 'When you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, the first thing you notice is the silence. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass. You throw it up to serve and hit it, hearing the sound of your own shot. The grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the quiet crowd make you feel like you are in a different world. The silence helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to think only about the game and the point I am playing. When a point ends, the silence breaks with applause and cheers. I hear them, but they feel far away. I don’t think about the 15,000 people watching me or the millions around the world. I am very focused as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, always told me it was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends I would play there and win. Before 2008, I played and lost to Federer twice, in the finals the two years before. Losing in 2006 was not so bad. I was happy to be there at age 20. Federer beat me easily because I didn’t believe in myself enough. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have done better. It wasn’t my skills that failed, but my mind. I cried a lot after that loss. Losing is always painful, but it’s worse when you know you had a chance. My uncle Toni, who is a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me. He even criticizes me when I win. But after that loss, he told me not to cry and that there would be more chances. I told him he didn’t understand, that it might have been my last chance. I know a professional athlete’s career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I missed a big one in 2007. Toni couldn’t make me feel better, but he was right. I got another chance in 2008. I was sure I learned from my loss the year before. I believed I would win. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends. We didn’t talk about the match. They knew I was already thinking about it in my mind. Until the match started, I needed to keep that space in my head for myself.'

A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall went to Africa in April 1957. She loved Africa and wrote to her family saying, "I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became well-known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made Jane famous by showing her work with chimpanzees in articles and TV shows. She also wrote books for children and adults, including a bestseller called "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages.

Jane Goodall is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century, like Marie Curie. Many stories about her life focus on her adventures and dreams, but they sometimes miss her real achievements. Jane's work helped us understand chimpanzees better. Before her, people did not know that chimpanzees eat meat or use tools. She showed that chimpanzees have emotions and social systems like humans. 

Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is very important for chimpanzee research. Her study of chimpanzees in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered a great scientific achievement. Jane changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves because chimpanzees are our closest relatives.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of becoming a scientist. When she was five years old, she disappeared one day. Her family and the police looked for her. Later, she came back with straw in her hair. She explained that she wanted to see how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours to watch. This curiosity was the start of her career as a biologist.

Shirley Ford is a voiceover artist. This means she uses her voice to play different characters. In one conversation, she spoke like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. People know her voices from children's TV shows, cartoons, and health and safety videos. She recently did a voiceover about back injuries and had to learn medical words quickly.

Shirley explains that doing voiceovers is more than just making funny voices. You have to make the script interesting for people who can't see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceovers, but they often don't get the job because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.

After school, Shirley took a drama course to become an actress. She also sang jingles for TV ads. One day, someone asked her to try out for a rabbit character in a cartoon. She thought it was funny but tried it anyway and got a big part. She realized she was good at voices and decided to focus on voiceover work. In her second film, she played the main character and her brother and mother.

Adult women often do voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter. Hiring child actors is complicated, so companies prefer adults. Shirley learns new voices by watching children's TV. She enjoys doing cartoons the most, but she also does educational videos and ads for things like vacuum cleaners. She says it's hard to sound excited about things she doesn't care about, but smiling while talking helps make her voice sound happy.

The competition for voiceover work is tough. A good showreel, which is a recording of what you can do, is very important. Shirley says it's worth investing in a strong showreel. She got to the top of her profession by working hard and not giving up. She suggests going to workshops to learn about voiceovers. Shirley loves voices and sometimes keeps speaking in a character's voice even after leaving the studio. Her children are used to her talking in different voices.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because being a cartoonist is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people stop dreaming about these jobs and think about more realistic ones, like being a lawyer or making car parts. It seems silly to think you can make money by drawing doodles like the ones in school notebooks. But some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. 

For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school papers, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college. After college, I showed my drawings to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that wanted political cartoons. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to live on.

To be a cartoonist, you don’t need a university degree, much money, or even to be great at drawing. You need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. It’s a hard job, and you should only try it if you can’t imagine doing anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and gives you time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t say no to work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, read a lot, and be curious about everything.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists had regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But now, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to make and sell your work. Cartoonists with good business skills often do better than those who are very artistic but not good at business.

I often meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they won’t show their work to anyone! To protect your work, you just need to draw a little ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it’s not a disaster – it can actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and getting rid of things I didn't need. I decided to throw away an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a black guitar made in Japan. I usually don't like to throw things away, so why did I want to throw this guitar away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it away when a young man came up to me. He looked confused and asked, "Are you really going to throw that away?" I said yes, but I already felt a little sad. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways. 

For years, I felt sad about what I did. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that surprised me. It was from a man named Keith Rushton, who fixes and sells guitars. He said, "I have your electric guitar." The guitar had been sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address sticker on the back of the guitar. He used my name to find me online and contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He offered to sell the guitar back to me. I was so happy I almost cried. Keith's price was fair, and I was glad my dad put those stickers on everything I owned, even my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this story!

My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s because it was popular then. I liked the sound of the classical guitar because it was calm and gentle. But I didn't get very good at it, so I switched to the electric guitar. At that time, punk music was popular, and you didn't have to play well to be a rock star. When I got my old guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. The guitar felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I picked it up and felt like I needed to stand up to play it. My fingers remembered how to play the chords, even though I couldn't draw them. My fingers hurt a little from pressing the strings, but it felt good. 

The electric guitar is not usually played alone, so I think I need to start a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

There has been a lot of talk about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who can't sleep well, I felt like I was the only one talking about how bad not sleeping enough is for our minds, bodies, and moods. People who can't sleep will tell you that sleep is very important for feeling good mentally, physically, and socially. It seems that people who have trouble sleeping know best how important sleep is. So, it's good that sleep is getting more attention now. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about dreams in these talks. We often lose dreams. When you wake up early, you miss the last part of sleep, which is mostly REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, where we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen in REM sleep, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they will spend six or seven years in REM. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This shows that dreams are important. When researchers found REM in 1953, many agreed with Sigmund Freud, a famous psychologist, who said that understanding dreams helps us understand our minds. But it wasn't that simple. Later studies showed that dreams might come more from physical processes than psychological ones. Now, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, says Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams are important. At a meeting, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study that showed actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams better than other people. He thinks that people who are interested in creativity use dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don't all people, like teachers and software designers, need to think creatively? Stickgold says dreams help us think in new and surprising ways, using what we know from the past and present to find new ideas. For example, Stickgold found that when people wake up from REM sleep and are asked to say what they think of a word, their answers are more original than when they wake up from other sleep stages. They think of unexpected things that make a kind of strange sense. This is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a bad dream, or one you can barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and ideas come so fast that I can hardly type them. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complicated world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, co-workers, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, you can see the sea, but there are empty frames on the walls. There are also photos of her two daughters. Susie is a famous copyist artist. She can paint like famous artists from the past, such as Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her paintings look so real that even art experts think they are the originals. The real paintings are worth millions, but Susie's copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on how long she works on them.

Susie has many clients, including galleries and private collectors. Some collectors like to show off her paintings as if they are the real ones. One famous person likes to say he has a Van Gogh, but it is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh'. Some people keep the original paintings in a bank and hang Susie's copies at home to save on insurance.

Susie is honest about her work. She makes her copies look very real and signs her name on the back. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real thing, and Susie does not do that. She knows people who have done it and got into trouble. Susie is not rich, but she is doing better now and does not want to risk her reputation.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator at a botanical garden. She did not earn much money, but it helped her learn to be very accurate. She has no regrets about that job, but she is happy to have found something that pays better.

When young artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw well and be accurate. She has studied a lot to do what she does. Susie can draw many things, but she likes French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas the most. Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie says it is not. The impressionists painted quickly but were also very careful, which is hard to do.

Susie does not create her own original art. She says her work is the result of years of training, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried to paint her own things, like fishing nets, but they looked like photos, not special. Susie is a perfectionist and likes to do things perfectly.

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur loved the sea more than anything else. She wanted to be the fastest person on the water. From a young age, she was very interested in sailing. She felt a special connection with the boats she sailed around the world. They worked together as one. When she was back on land, normal life seemed boring. People always asked her about the race, and she quickly wanted to return to the ocean. She liked to challenge herself against nature, even in dangerous places.

Ellen came second in the Vendée Globe, a solo race around the world. She showed me her small boat, Kingfisher, where she lived and worked for 94 days. She talked about how she planned everything carefully, even counting how many rolls of kitchen paper she needed. Preparation was very important to her. She showed me her food, a small gas stove, and bags of medical supplies. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat. It is small, beautiful, and can be damaged. She realized this during a trip to South Georgia, an island in the south Atlantic. She helped with a bird survey there and saw many old whaling stations. This made her think about how people take what they want and then leave. 

When I met Ellen at her office, she was finishing a phone call. She explained why we need to act now to save the planet. She said, "No one is making coal, oil, or gas anymore. We have to find a way to not use everything up." At first, she told people to use less, but now she talks about re-using things. She is very interested in things like reusable carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories and talked to governments and businesses about using fewer non-renewable resources.

Ellen started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people think about a sustainable future. She says she misses the adventure of being at sea, but her new work is important. She wants to use her voice to help the planet. She says, "I may have been the fastest around the world, but this work is more important than anything I've done before."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he does it, he could become very famous. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to inspire them to go outside and try new things. Jordan's team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero'. Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

Some experienced climbers think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb Everest. They say a young climber might be strong enough, but they worry if a teenager is emotionally ready. They also think a young person might not have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros know about these concerns. Paul says, ‘I know people criticize us, but I can’t focus on that – we have a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.’

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father wants him to? Paul says, ‘This is not about me trying to be famous because of my son. At first, Jordan talked about doing this later, but we thought: ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it.’ When I ask Jordan why he likes this challenge, he says, ‘I just focus on reaching my goal.’

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record challenge. This makes Jordan think. People might say that trying to break records is more important than enjoying the climb, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to share his story. This means writing online, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, ‘If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym.’
