This was seen in the Rugby World Cup, where home teams won against stronger opponents by playing with determination and not giving up. As one referee said, "It's the law of the jungle out there."

Text: "‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said the golfer Gary Player about 50 years ago. This saying is famous in sports. Many athletes and coaches like it. The saying means that practice makes you better, not really luckier. This idea is part of the nature-nurture debate. This debate asks if talent is something you are born with or something you learn. 

Many people think practice is more important than natural talent. Psychologist Anders Ericsson said you can become an expert in anything with 10,000 hours of practice. This idea is in books like Outliers and Talent Is Overrated. These books say practice is the most important thing. But, as David Epstein explains in his book, practice alone is not always enough. 

Epstein looks at why some people are very good at what they do. He travels to places like Kenya, Sweden, and Alaska to find answers. In Alaska, he learns that sled dogs' success might be because of their natural drive, not just training. This suggests that some traits might be genetic. 

Epstein talks about the difference between nature (what you are born with) and nurture (what you learn). He says both are important for top athletes. For example, if Usain Bolt grew up in the US, he might have been a good basketball player instead of a sprinter. Epstein also discusses race and gender in sports. He asks why men and women compete separately if practice is the only thing that matters. This shows how complex the topic is."

A recent international report shows that many children in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why children today feel this way. In her book, "Kith," she explains that children spend too much time indoors, watching TV or using computers, and have lost touch with nature. Griffiths believes this is the main problem. 

A study talked to children and found that many would be happier if they could play outside more. People over 40 often remember their childhoods fondly, saying they had more freedom to explore and play outside. They think this was healthier than how children live today. However, these adults are the ones who now keep their children inside because they worry about safety.

Griffiths argues that fear of danger helps toy and gadget companies sell more products to keep kids entertained indoors. She also talks about how some children are given medicine for being restless or are made to wear goggles for playground games. Griffiths is upset about these things and writes passionately about them.

While her ideas are interesting, Griffiths sometimes goes too far. She compares how children are treated today to racism, which seems extreme. She also believes children should have more freedom to explore and take risks. She says children need small accidents to learn how to avoid bigger ones later. But she doesn't explain how to make sure these accidents are safe.

Griffiths thinks all children should be free to explore, but not all children are the same. Some are shy and prefer to stay at home. The real problem might be forcing all children to live the same way, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this is not because of school. Most problems in life cannot be solved with formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play. Those that have more to learn play more. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because they need to learn more. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how adults and mammals have always learned. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, and moral lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned through play. They include thinking creatively, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is important for success. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. Creative thinkers can help us succeed. The creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he found it again after leaving school. He called his work 'combinatorial play'. He imagined chasing a sunbeam to develop his theory of relativity. We cannot teach creativity, but we can lose it through schooling that focuses on set questions and answers. More important than creativity is getting along with others, caring, and cooperating. Children are born wanting to play with others, and this helps them learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit if they want. This makes play democratic. School has become harder: breaks are shorter, homework is more, and grades are more important. Outside school, adult-led sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults have replaced unsupervised play. Adults now feel they must solve children's problems. These changes have been slow but big. They are due to social factors like parents' fears, experts warning about dangers, less close neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children need more play, not more school. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change this trend. We must give childhood back to children. They must be allowed to play and explore to grow into strong adults ready for the future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn help them contact employers directly. In the past, people had to do things like stand outside an office with a "hire me" sign to get noticed. But with more access to employers, there is also a bigger chance to make mistakes.

For example, a young person in the US tried to connect with a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many important contacts that the young person thought could help him get a job. However, the executive was not happy with this request. She did not want to share her contacts with someone she did not know. She rejected his request and sent a very rude message, which many people saw online. People were shocked by her message, and she might regret how she said it. But this situation shows young people that they need to be careful when using social media for work.

Social media can be dangerous for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly. Many young people are making mistakes. Social media like Facebook and Twitter have been a big part of their social lives for years. When I was a teenager, social media was a place to have fun and be different. You could talk to someone online and then ignore them at school. You could change your Facebook page to look more interesting. But using social media for work is different. Some young people do not see the difference.

We learned to be bold and confident online, but this does not always work for job hunting. Just because many people liked your Facebook posts, it does not mean you can impress employers on LinkedIn. We need to understand that what we learned as teenagers does not help us in the job world. We must meet employers' standards to succeed.

Employers often say young job seekers on professional sites are too familiar and seem arrogant. This makes older people think we feel entitled. But many young people are just desperate to find jobs, which is why they use social media. This impression of arrogance can hurt their chances, even if they have the skills to be good workers.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them. Maybe you can help with research or something else. This gives you a better chance of getting a good reply. Do not send the same message to everyone, and be polite. Remember, social media can help you make good contacts, but you need to use it carefully to avoid problems.

Text: 'It is hard to say what will happen to newspapers in the future. Some people think they will disappear. Since 2000, many UK newspapers have lost a lot of readers. In the USA, only 26% of people get their news from newspapers now, compared to 45% in 2001. Some people think newspapers will stop being printed in 15 years. But old media often survive. In 1835, a journalist said books and theatre were finished, but they are still here. Theatre survived newspapers, cinema, and TV. Radio is still popular even with TV, and cinema is still here despite videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records are popular again, with sales up a lot since 2008. Newspapers were once new too. They became popular in the 19th century because of new technology like the steam press and telegraph. People started to want news regularly because they saw the world was always changing. In the past, people only noticed the seasons and big events like floods or disease. Journalism as a job started in the 19th century. Before that, people did not need news every day or week. Newspapers have a set format and schedule, which can be limiting. Online news is different. People can read it whenever they want and choose what interests them. Online news can update quickly and correct mistakes fast. There is no limit to how much can be written. But online news often focuses on being first and getting comments, which can cause confusion. In the past, news was shared in places like markets or taverns, where it mixed with rumors. We might be going back to that. Newspapers have not always explained the world well. They might disappear, or they might help us understand the world better in the future.'

If humans were comfortable under the moon and stars, we would enjoy walking in the dark. Many animals are active at night and feel at home in the dark. But we are daytime creatures, with eyes made for sunlight. This is part of our nature, even if we don't often think about it. We have changed the night by adding light everywhere. This is like building a dam in a river. It helps us, but it also causes problems called light pollution. Light pollution happens when lights are not designed well. They shine up into the sky instead of down where we need them. This extra light changes the night and affects animals and people. It can change how animals migrate, reproduce, and eat. 

In the past, the idea of light pollution would not make sense. Imagine walking to London at night in 1800. It was the biggest city in the world, with almost a million people. They used candles, torches, and lanterns for light. Only a few houses had gas lights, and there were no streetlights yet. From far away, you would smell London before you saw its dim light. We have lit up the night as if no animals lived there, but many animals are active at night. Light is very strong and attracts many animals. Birds can get confused by bright lights and fly around them until they are too tired. Some birds even sing at night because of artificial light.

People used to think light pollution only bothered astronomers, who need to see the stars clearly. Most of us don't need to see the night sky for work, but we do need darkness. Darkness is important for our health, just like light. Changing our natural sleep patterns can make us sick. Our sleep and wake cycles are connected to the Earth's light and dark cycles. Changing these rhythms is like changing our balance. In the end, we are affected by light pollution just like animals near bright lights. We have lost our connection to the stars and the natural day and night cycle. Light pollution makes us forget our place in the universe and the beauty of a starry night.

The boss of a big company said that his company will not count how many days off employees take. This idea came from another internet company that did the same thing. The boss got the idea from an email from his daughter, which was shared in newspapers. Some people think this is just a way to make the company look good, but is it a good idea?

The internet company is small, with 2,000 workers and one service. The big company has 50,000 workers and many different services like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want" might work better in a small company where everyone knows each other's work. In a big company, it is harder to know if taking time off will hurt the business.

The boss said workers can take time off if they are sure their work is done and it won't hurt the business or their careers. But can anyone be that sure? When you take a holiday, work piles up. This can make people feel guilty about taking time off, which can lead to stress and less work done in the long run.

There might also be pressure from other workers about who takes time off and when. In many companies, people work late, and this could lead to a "no holiday" culture where people don't take time off because they want to get promoted. If there are no set holidays, people might feel they can't take time off because they don't want to look lazy.

Modern technology means we can get work messages anytime, anywhere. The internet company started the unlimited leave policy because workers asked how this new way of working fits with old holiday rules. If the company can't track work hours, why should it track holiday time? But if there are no set work hours, all hours could be work hours. Workers might feel they are always being watched, which can be stressful.

Workers have a right to a certain amount of paid holiday because rest is important for health. The good things like more creativity and productivity that come from unlimited leave can happen without this policy. So, I am not sure if "take as much holiday as you want" is really what the company wants or if it will work.

Journal-based peer review is a process where experts check a scientific paper before it is published. This is to make sure the research is good and not wrong. It can take up to a year to review a paper. Some people think this is important to make sure the research is trustworthy, but others are not so sure. 

The way scientific publishing works is changing. Preprints are part of this change. Preprints are drafts of papers shared online before they are reviewed. They help share new research quickly so others can read and discuss it. Publishing in journals is often about gaining fame and advancing careers, which can lead to problems. Scientists might leave out important data to get published in top journals. Reviewers sometimes focus more on whether a paper is interesting rather than if it is good science.

Preprints have been around for 20 years, but not everyone uses them. Some scientists worry that journals will not accept papers that were shared as preprints. Others fear that without peer review, bad science might be published. However, preprints allow for open discussion and feedback from many people around the world. 

Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience with preprints. She said that preprints allowed for open discussion and feedback, which is not always possible with traditional journals. Preprints also help share negative results, which are important but often ignored by journals. 

Preprints make it easier for more people to read and cite papers. They focus on the research itself, not just where it is published. This openness and sharing are important in the scientific community.

When I ask my literature students what a poem is, they often say it is like a "painting in words." These answers don't satisfy me or them. One day, I asked a group to pick an object and write two paragraphs about it. The first paragraph should describe it like a scientist, and the second should be from the object's point of view, called "Poem." One student wrote:

Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I help people breathe. I am used only in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need me. The object? An oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class see how poetry is different from anything else. The exercise was fun and led to good discussions.

When I was in school, poetry was confusing to me. I thought poems were puzzles that stopped me from understanding and feeling. After school, many people lose interest in poetry. Sometimes, you see a poem and it stands out because it is not like regular writing. You try to read it, but often feel let down because it is hard to understand. Still, you feel good for trying.

What do we want from poems? Are they for deep feelings, beautiful images, or clever thoughts? Maybe. But for tears, we watch movies; for information, we read articles. Novels let us escape, paintings please our eyes, and music combines words and melody beautifully. But poems have something special: they can be unclear, like life often is.

If you search for "poem" online, it leads to "poetry," which is described as a type of art using the beauty and rhythm of language. But the word "poem" comes from Greek, meaning "a thing made," and a poet is "a maker of things." So, what kind of thing is a poem? Some poets say poems are like wild animals or machines, but these ideas don't fully explain poems. The best part of comparing poems to other things is the discussion it creates. It can change how we think about machines or animals and help us see things differently.

A poem can stick in our minds, like song lyrics. Words and music together are powerful, like schoolyard rhymes. Words can be strong, like sticks and stones. A poem in a newspaper or magazine can have a big impact, even though it is just ink on paper. Poems take up space that could be used for longer articles or ads, but they are not made to be sold like other writings. Poems are special and can surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. It cost £70, which was a lot of money back then. My wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, I have found many brooches and coins, and each one makes me happy because it connects me to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion. 

One rainy February afternoon, I had some free time and decided to go to a place I knew. It mostly had old farming tools. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I almost ignored it but decided to check. I dug half a meter down and saw a round, golden ball. I thought it might be brass, like curtain rails I found before, so I didn't get too excited. But as I cleaned it, I saw it was a beautiful, patterned loop. I realized it looked like the Great Torc, a famous necklace from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. 

I took it to my car and drove home, looking at it the whole way. At home, I washed it in the sink. I called Marion and showed her. She was surprised. I told her it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on because we didn't want to damage it. I hid it in our wardrobe, but I was worried, so I later hid it under a floorboard in my office.

The law says you must report such finds within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc before giving it up. I even showed it to a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office. The registrar was surprised when he saw it. The torc was checked and sold to my local council. It is now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was shared between the field owner and me. But the torc is more than just money. It is something I saved for the nation. People ask if I will stop detecting now, but I still enjoy finding brooches and coins. Like a fisherman who catches a big fish, I keep going, hoping for another great find.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things to do when I travel, but I don't talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends tell me about their busy travel plans, full of activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. I wonder what they would think if they knew my travel plans include time for naps in the afternoon and lazy mornings in bed. Sleeping better is a nice part of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—more than 12 hours most days. There were noisy birds nearby, but it didn't bother me. Away from home, I could sleep deeply and have many dreams. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. I think sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we see, hear, and smell new things. We take in new cultures, music, and landscapes. We process all this new information while we sleep, which makes travel sleep more intense. Sleep also changes with different places. People often talk about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local habits is more important. For example, on the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is just one hour ahead of New York, where I live, it takes me days to get used to their sleep pattern. Once I do, I feel like I truly belong there. I remember a day in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, we all took naps on hammocks and sofas. I finally understood the Latin American tradition of the siesta. I shared not just sleep, but a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is special because I remember it. Away from my usual routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds while I sleep. If 'slow travel' means enjoying every moment instead of rushing, then sleep is the slowest activity. Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed and tell my friends that travel sleep is an activity too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? Be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a pretty layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one looks best on you," she said kindly to her customer. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a face. "But it is so boring," she said. "Every woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little hat will make me stand out." She touched the red and black small top hat on her head. "Yes," she said, "this is the one I want." Mia smiled and agreed that the woman would stand out at the wedding. She thought about her own daughter, Jen. It was Jen's thirtieth birthday today, and they were having a family party. Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious to meet Jen's friend, Tattie, who was coming too. Mia's husband, Jeff, had asked, "What kind of name is Tattie?" Mia explained, "It's short for Tatiana. I think it’s nice." Jeff didn’t like fancy things and always spoke his mind. He would have told the woman in the shop that she chose the wrong hat. He often told Mia, "You’re too polite." An hour later, Mia closed her shop and went home. Her shop was next to her house, so it only took forty seconds to get home. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia turned the barn next to their house into a shop. Jeff was unsure. "Do you think people want hats?" he asked. Mia knew people wanted hats for special occasions. She was right. After Jen helped her make a website, Mia’s Hats became popular. Women came from far away to her shop in Little Pelham. They could try on many hats in a friendly place. Mia also sold handbags and costume jewelry now.

Lawrence Okoye has moved from London to Atlanta, USA. He is on an exciting sports journey. Lawrence used to compete in the discus throw and even reached the Olympic final. Now, he is trying something new: American football. Even though he has never played American football before, he might join a big team in the USA. In Atlanta, he is learning about his new position in the sport.

Lawrence is 21 years old and from London. It seems surprising that he might play for a top American football team. But Lawrence is used to surprising people. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on sports instead. He played rugby before and became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world in just 20 months.

Lawrence went to Atlanta for warm-weather training for discus. He was getting ready for the world championships. He thought about American football before but only decided to try it when he got to the USA. He read about NFL trials in Atlanta and applied, even though he had never played the game. He was not nervous about the trials and did very well in the tests. Coaches told him he has the skills needed for American football. He knows he has to work hard.

Lawrence is waiting to hear if he will be selected for an NFL team. He is not worried because there is no pressure on him. He remembers his Olympic experience, where he did not do as well as he wanted, but he is proud he made it to the final. If American football does not work out, he can return to discus, which he loves. Lawrence is trying to achieve a dream he had since he was a schoolboy. He has made careful decisions about his sports career.

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see it was already daytime. Looking out of the window, I saw the empty land below. The dark colors of brown and green made me feel better because, even though it was mid-September, it had not started snowing in Siberia yet. I saw no signs of people, just mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow. He was flying to a far place to sell safety clothes to the local mining industries. His English was almost as bad as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I explained that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with only a one-way ticket because I wanted to return home to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I told him I believed there was a road, though not many people used it now. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend called Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked unsure and said one word, "Holodna" (cold), pointing outside. I tried to show Sergei with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, but I didn't tell him that because my trip was self-funded, I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at low prices. I wasn't sure they would be good enough, especially my big postman’s over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students sitting tiredly. Some were taking notes without energy. The lecturer kept talking. I was thinking hard about a question. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my messy writing, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still learning to control my classes, the job was good for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, often fulfilling, and, of course, there were long holidays to have adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I used these holidays to meet Al. He loved adventures after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more exciting than teaching: to cycle around the world. Since that first ride we took together, Al had been setting himself bigger and bigger challenges. This trip around the world by bike was his biggest challenge so far. Sometimes he thought the ride or the road would be too hard for him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an amazing adventure, finding that he could handle each new challenge even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the people who said he couldn't do it. He was doing something that scared him almost every day, and it made him feel alive.

In the Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns flying through tall pylons, which are 15 to 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to see what it feels like to be part of this. 

An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first form said I was healthy, and the second said I would empty my pockets because small things can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay aware of where I was. Someone told me, "The horizon is your best friend," and the pilot would tell me where to look. I also promised to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety talk. They told me not to touch anything. When we were moving down the runway, I tried not to touch the important pedals with my feet or the switches with my hands. I decided I would not relax and enjoy the flight. 

In high-speed flying, you need to stay calm and focused. You have to tense up and relax at the right times. Panicking is not good. This was not comforting as we started moving fast down the runway. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes. The plane took off, and we quickly turned right. It was a strong move, and I felt the air push out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and took short breaths. For a moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned left and dived, making my stomach feel strange. 

Seconds later, we were 10 meters above the ground, flying between two pylons at 400 km per hour. I felt excited for a moment, but then we turned sharply right. We hadn't even done any acrobatics yet. For two minutes, I got to fly the plane. My hand was shaking, and the plane shook too because it was very sensitive. Then Dario said something, but instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. "Are you okay?" he asked. "Yup," I said. "Have you had enough?" "No," I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane in a full circle. 

Some people might find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. But I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, when we were upside down, I heard a small voice saying, "Relax, relax, look up." I looked up and saw some fields. The flight lasted 10 minutes. It was "soft" compared to what pilots experience in a race. To show this, Dario ate sandwiches happily after we landed. I didn't eat for hours, and that night I dreamed about the loop over and over again.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have seen polar bears in a nature documentary, he probably filmed them. He likes it when the temperature is -18C. Allan studied to be a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first love, and he learned how to survive in cold places. His big chance came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. ‘I took the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I knew I wanted to be a wildlife cameraman. It had everything: travel, adventure, underwater.’ He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many big TV wildlife series. ‘I started at a good time. When I began, not many people had been to the Antarctic. There were people who filmed coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. I became the cold man. It was like all these amazing scenes were waiting to be filmed.’ The camera and technology were very simple when he started 35 years ago. ‘It is easier to film today. Before, you had to remember what you filmed. Now, with digital technology, you can film a lot and see it right away. You had to think about what shots you needed next and what you missed. You filmed less because film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.’ ‘My value is my experience in cold places. I know how it feels. I have spent so much time on sea ice it feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes, but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases, or mosquitoes.’ Wildlife filming, Allan says, has great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes, but he could not tell which birds they were. When Allan got permission to film for a big TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he knew it would not be easy. It is a place with polar bears and is very dangerous. Usually -32C in April, the wind is strong, and carrying cameras in the deep snow is very hard. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow for 23 days, Allan saw just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, he says, he was living like a bear. ‘We find a new hole and wait. We move to stay warm. After five hours of watching, I see something. The camera is ready, and I look through the viewfinder. Nothing for a few seconds, then a black nose. The nose becomes a muzzle, then a head, and in less than a minute, she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow. She looks at me but is not worried. I think this can’t get much better … then she slides down the slope. I think she is having fun,’ he says, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. ‘It’s their first view of the world … It’s show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.’ Now Allan wants to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and see the impact of it. He says he could make an amazing documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow was the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies. He had to swim in very cold water and face frostbite and polar bears. Eight months later, he also reached the South Pole. Now, he is back in the Arctic for a new, bigger challenge. Pen and two friends will walk 1,000 kilometers to the North Pole in three months. They will measure the ice thickness and density. No one has done this before, and the information is very important for scientists. This will show how global warming is affecting the ice.

Pen was trained for this. As a child, he was looked after by a woman who worked for a famous explorer, Scott of the Antarctic. She made him go out in the cold with little clothing to make him tough. His father loved cold adventures, and Pen became very strong. Pen is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps with his polar guide business and says she worries more when he is at home because he is always thinking about the Arctic. For fun, Mary once raced against him in a mountain event. She finished an hour before him.

Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. Pen finds it hard to leave them this time. Last time, he told his son to take care of the family, which was too much for the boy. So, this time, Pen will not contact them much while he is away. He is busy getting ready for the trip. On the ice, fixing things is very hard, so he must prepare well. Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, a photographer, will join him. A team of six will fly in supplies.

Being in a team is stressful for Pen. He is also worried because he is turning 47 and has not trained enough. Organizing things took more time. Pen believes this mission is important for science. Before, reaching the North Pole was a personal goal. Now, the data will help scientists, and more people will learn about the Arctic. Pen says their skills are now very useful.

I took a year off from my usual activities. I was an Olympian, which was amazing. During this time, I did some writing, worked on TV, and spoke to businesses and schools. These activities were fun, but I missed competing. I wanted to stay fit in case I wanted to try for the Olympics again. So, I started running marathons and doing triathlons. 

Then, TV presenter Ben Fogle asked me if I wanted to row across the Atlantic Ocean with him. I love rowing and missed it, but I wasn't ready to train every day. I talked to my rowing friends about the race, but they weren't interested. I knew if I joined the race, I would want to win. I wasn't sure if Ben was the best partner for winning, but the idea of being an underdog was interesting. 

Ben was already planning to do the race and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat. We talked about the costs, which were very high. The boat and equipment alone cost £70,000. We thought we had a good chance, but it would be hard work. I also had to think about losing money from not working while racing. Speaking at business events is a good way to earn money, and people are interested in my past achievements. But I wanted a new goal, like rowing across the Atlantic, to talk about.

Preparing for this adventure taught me to appreciate the life of a full-time athlete. Training for the Olympics was hard, but everything was organized with doctors and dieticians. I was worried people would think I just wanted to be on TV by racing with Ben. But during our preparations, I realized the race was more about mental strength than just rowing. Ben had done tough challenges before, like the Marathon des Sables and living on a deserted island. But he wasn't good at rowing. I was surprised by how little he knew about it, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I should have known his skill level when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle, in the far north of Finland. I was 26 years old and feeling restless. I wanted to see the cold and quiet places of the Arctic, maybe because London was too noisy and crowded for me. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They let me work as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, many tourists come for sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow. These rides can last from one hour to five days. Anna and Pasi started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. They also have a second place called the 'wilderness farm', which is pretty but has no reliable electricity or running water. They said I could join them for three months if I understood the work would be hard. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical,’ they said. I started packing right away.

November 6, London On my flight, I looked at a page with pictures of more than 100 huskies. I was supposed to learn their names before I arrived, but I felt nervous and couldn't focus. I put the page down and looked out the window. People say that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, with flowers and leaves opening. But I felt like I was seeing the opposite, with winter moving south and rivers freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus ride north was just what I hoped for. We drove through dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrived at the farm after dark and was given boots and sent outside into the cold. 'Do you want to start right away?’ Anna asked. It wasn’t really a question. I followed the barking sounds, which got louder as I reached the dogsheds. Three people were busy getting the huskies ready and putting them in harnesses. The dogs were very excited and eager to go. I could hardly hear to introduce myself, and the others were too busy to talk. I stood on the side and petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone waved at me to get in a sled, and I almost fell into it. A command was given, and we started moving into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

November 15, Hetta It didn’t take long to become part of the husky guide team, but first, I had to answer questions about what I could do. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asked. I didn’t know what to say. I had never driven a snowmobile, hadn’t done woodwork since school, and never used an axe. 'Do you have a driving licence?’ someone asked. I nodded, feeling relieved. The basics of dog-sledding are easy to learn: lean into corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. But other things are more complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and giving water to the dogs are hard in the cold. Water freezes quickly, so we make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head was full of instructions, and my muscles hurt from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled by excited huskies. But I felt proud. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I emailed my friends. 'In the snow.’

On that day, Radcliffe ran very fast and crossed the finish line. The press was amazed by her run. Her time was so good that she could compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Reporters asked her about emu oil, a natural treatment. Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had told her to use it after she had an accident with a bike while training. Radcliffe says she didn't really understand how big her achievement was at the time. She felt it was just what she was supposed to do that day. Her team had a motto: no limits.

During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her team, listening to the radio. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, was with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried if she could keep running so fast. Hartmann was angry about this but understood why someone might think it was risky. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes. She had run 41 kilometers very fast and still managed to sprint the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't think anyone would beat that time soon. Radcliffe thought she could do it again next year, but it didn't happen.

After the race, people wondered how she beat the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with her a lot, helping her with the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said she could handle a lot of pain. He would have to press very hard on her muscles, and it hurt his thumbs. Hartmann traveled 13 hours from Ireland to her training place in France. When he arrived, her husband said, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." She was ready for a two-hour session. She worked very hard, and that made her great. Hartmann spent so much time with her that other athletes were upset.

Radcliffe doesn't know why no one has beaten her record. She trained very hard, but she thinks others are more talented. She thought Mary Keitany might do it. Radcliffe says maybe people are racing each other instead of racing themselves. She always pushed herself, even when she was winning. That marathon was the best race of her career. She never ran that fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, came out, I didn't know how people would like it. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' in Britain. I thought our show was new and different, but I was still worried. Would people like a cooking show that talked about techniques, history, memories, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and scared. I didn't need to worry. The show was a success and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my restaurant experiences. Each project feels like a journey, whether it's about the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection', each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often a real one, with travel and meeting new people. In Search of Total Perfection is the latest book, where you travel the world to meet amazing people, like a man who makes the best golden pasta. These people have spent many years trying to make perfect food. Perfection is different for everyone. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was hard, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was not included. But after a long meeting, the TV team and I made a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on their feelings, memories, and surroundings. I knew from the start that I wouldn't say the recipes were the best. But I thought I could use my skills and knowledge to find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says 'perfection' means being perfect, but it also means improving through trying new things. The TV series let me explore new foods, people, and places. I was excited about this, just like when I started in this business. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. Some of my adventures included visiting a factory that had the wrong tomatoes and a dairy farm that wasn't good enough to film. I also tried new techniques, like hand-milking a cow to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burning my house down to make a perfect pizza.

We were still far from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and went off the road into a field. It stopped moving. John got out and looked at the engine. He stood there for a long time. Then he said, "I don’t know what I’m doing," and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried and said, "We can’t stay here forever." The field was big, with grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea because it was safer to be on her side. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. John went to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay on the grass and asked for a story. Bea lay next to her. I told them a story about two birds I heard talking in London. They talked about breadcrumbs, other birds, and the weather. They even argued about a worm. Bea said it was silly because no one understands birds. I said I did, but I wasn’t sure. Mum was asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped push the van to a hotel. Bea stayed in the van, but the boys waved and smiled at her. We went into a café near the road. John said it might be expensive, but Mum said we’d just have tea. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum said it was like syrup. We stayed at the café all day while John looked at the engine. He said it was a miracle the van got us this far. Mum made a bed for us outside in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on the ground. John said we’d have to be towed into Marrakech. Later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind us. Bea didn’t want to move, so John carried her to the truck. She sat in the front with the driver. I wondered how we’d get home since our van needed to be towed. I thought maybe we could take a boat to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like her. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city. Lucy didn't hear her name well because of the noise. It was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy. They spoke English well and talked about the music they were playing and their travels.

Lucy told them, "I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer." It sounded impressive, but she didn't really want to go. She didn't want to do many of the things that took her around the world, like concerts and competitions. She missed so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. She didn't even want to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. Her mom had filled out the application and sent in a CD without telling her. "I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in," her mom said. Lucy thought it was more like her mom didn't want her to say no.

The guy from Tokyo asked, "Tanglewood?" Lucy said, "Yeah." He asked, "How old are you?" "Fifteen," she replied. He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, "Wow." Lucy didn't mean to brag. It was hard to know when she was just sharing or showing off. "It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're trying," she explained. Liesel/Louisa left to talk to someone else, but the guy from Tokyo stayed. He asked if she had been to Japan. Lucy said, "Once. When I was, like, eight."

Then, Lucy's grandfather came and said, "Lucy, let me introduce you to someone." He took her away from the conversation. "And don't get too friendly with the competition," he said. "They're not the competition," Lucy replied. "Everyone is the competition," her grandfather said. He made her talk to important people at the party. Lucy smiled and nodded, but she only heard about half of what was said.

In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, "You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are." Lucy liked being somebody, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young. Being a concert pianist didn't make her special to the kids at her old school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro. But in places like this festival, she knew she mattered.

Dad said, "It's not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to go out into the real world." It's hard to argue with him, so I wanted to see what experts say. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, feel like they belong, and are learning important skills for the digital age. 

Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social networking is a big part of growing up today. Teenagers live in it, not just use it like adults do. It's not good or bad; it depends on how you use it. Jim Matthews, a social media expert, says social media is like the youth clubs parents went to when they were young. It helps teenagers find out who they are and learn to get along with others.

Professor Keith Davidson, a psychologist, says being a teenager is about asking, "Who am I?" Social media can help you find your identity. You can share your favorite music or sports and see different opinions. Research shows that people who use social media a lot are not as self-centered as those who don't. It can also help shy people because talking online can be easier than face-to-face.

Professor Andrew Phillips studies how young people use social media. He thinks it helps quiet people with special interests connect with others. If you like a rare type of music and only a few people at school like it too, you can find a group online and feel less alone.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, says young people who find new interests online and create their own content are using social networks well. Teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what they like. Photo-sharing sites help photographers learn and share their work. This can help in jobs because businesses use social media to sell products. If you have many friends on social networks, they can be your customers.

Matthews agrees that teenagers who use social media creatively will benefit when they start working. Many sites let you work with others to create and share content. Working together is an important skill for jobs today.

Text: 'When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they don't usually think of a long trip through nine western states in the US and a part of Canada. But my parents wanted something different for our summer vacation this year. My dad planned a big family trip. He and my mom kept saying, "Not enough people do this anymore," while my twin brother and I looked at each other, thinking, "There are probably good reasons why!" In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, food, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With just enough space for us in the car, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." As we left our big home for smaller places to stay over the next five thousand miles, I wondered what we were getting into. We drove west through Oklahoma. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under very dark, starry skies, but only after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We learned that on the road, cows have the right-of-way! The next day, we got up early and started driving again. I noticed a pattern. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to feel the same, but each adventure was different. We walked in the Great Sand Dunes and went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that town gave us a hint of what we would experience later. We learned that roads for Jeeps are best for Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of old and new things. We got used to traffic because of road work. We laughed when we saw big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument. We saw many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sun set over bear areas near the roads. Traffic would stop to let bears cross, and we had a close encounter with one, which gave us unforgettable memories. As we traveled, life at home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with no internet or phone service, didn't make us less excited. Instead, we enjoyed the beautiful views. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we drove back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to a faraway place to find something amazing. It was nice to be home again, and I didn't fight with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our trip to look through. I knew I would remember the unplanned and spontaneous moments.'

Rose Frost was sixteen years old. She was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school and live at the college. She had a nice room with a kitchen and study area. She also had free Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would still watch over Amy.

Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only remembered a little about her grandmother from holidays. She never knew her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, Rose’s parents were not very happy, but Daisy wanted to know her granddaughter again. Rose did not know why her parents did not like her grandma, but they had a disagreement in the past. Rose was ten years old when she last saw her grandmother, but she had happy memories.

Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy liked to meet people and bring them together. Rose would soon have dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips. This made Rose smile. Her grandmother was not a typical old lady. Daisy went to many social events.

Before moving, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was sensible and mature. She knew about healthy eating, exercise, and sleep. Rose wanted independence. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, and go out without asking every time. She didn’t want to be nagged about homework or staying out late. Daisy understood. Rose’s mother gave her a new phone for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They agreed to trust each other. Daisy would trust Rose to make good decisions, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If there were problems, they would talk about it.

Rose was not a wild child. Her school friends were like her, so her school reports and exam results were always good. In five weeks, Rose would start a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. It was her fourth school in five years, so she was used to it. This was the last time because she would start her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new beginning in her life.

Charlotte Grainger says her primary school teacher was the first to think she might write a novel. Charlotte thought writing a book would be a big achievement because it seemed hard. She didn't know what other teenagers were doing, like being in the Olympics. When she turned 13, she decided to try writing a book. Now, the book she started then is about to be published. She told her old teacher, who was surprised. The teacher thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte didn't understand why she should wait if she could be good at it now.

It's a winter afternoon at Charlotte's publisher's office. Even though I knew I was going to talk to a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was surprised to see a teenager there. The book is a big achievement: the story is strong and full of action. Nothing about it, except the age of the main character, shows it was written by a teenager. A public relations person is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she doesn't. Charlotte is confident and smart, but also calm.

Charlotte knows she is young. I ask her about the difficult questions in her book. She says, "I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don't have many life lessons to share," she laughs. "I don't think my age limits my understanding, but I'm not very wise either. I just wanted to explore the idea of taking responsibility."

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are shown in books. She says there are three types: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows nothing, and the awkward teenager who isn't good socially. Reading about these types annoyed her. "What if you're basically fine? There aren't many stories about characters who are okay. Some writers make teenagers feel they can't know who they are because they aren't experienced. This can hurt their confidence."

Charlotte loves reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost stopped her from writing. "Books by my favorite fantasy writers talk about deep things. I asked myself: do I have to do this to write a good book?" She likes a book called How Not to Write a Novel. "It says if the reader guesses what will happen, the suspense is gone."

Some might say Charlotte's parents, who are journalists, helped her get her book published. Her father's friend in publishing helped get her book read. She knows she was lucky because getting a first novel read is hard, no matter the writer's age. "Every writer needs support and luck, but after that, you're on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don't take things for granted," Charlotte says.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, went first. He skied down the slope towards the jump. He went fast and flew into the air, but something was wrong. We watched closely. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and fell head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On other skiing holidays, I liked practising turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how to do it. I was afraid people would laugh at me. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training centre in the US. It had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps with fake snow. Students jumped and tried new tricks, landing in foam cubes. After practising inside, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the centre’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers just went down the slopes and hoped for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat part behind the jump before the slope goes down again. Land in the right place, and you keep moving. Land on the flat, and you stop suddenly, which hurts. That’s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to make my body go fast towards the jump. My legs would slow down, and I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I’d hate being inside, but bouncing was fun. Some exercises were like ski-jumping moves, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body does in the air. Gareth talked to us as we practised. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work. Every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, then found myself in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more problems before I finally landed right. Gareth was as happy as I was, and I felt proud. But that didn’t last long. On the last run of the day, I didn’t slow down before the jump, landed in the right place, but then saw my skis sliding down the slope without me."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty, and you hold on tight as the ride stops and then slowly goes up. There is a pause, and then a fast drop makes your stomach feel funny. You move quickly forward, turn left, and go upside down. Everything is a blur, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose to be there, like many others who pay to enter theme parks every year.

Amusement parks are a big business. They have exciting rides to attract people. Behind these rides, there are many people working hard. There are engineers, designers, and marketing experts. They make sure the rides are fun and safe. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' sounds like a dream job for a child. But it is a big challenge. Designers must make rides that are fun and a little scary, but not dangerous. They also need to create new things to keep people coming back.

Many people think rollercoasters are getting more intense. But most of the ideas used today were created by John Miller, a designer from the early 20th century. Back then, rides were more extreme, but now designers have to follow rules and use certain track designs.

I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer,' said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts said it’s about making people feel like they are being thrown around but still safe. The best rides tell a story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and have exciting features like tall drops or many twists.

Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and trying new things are important. Jeff Hornick, a theme park director, agreed. He said designers need to love thrills to understand what people want and to test the rides.

I asked if new technology like virtual reality will change rollercoasters. Walker said not to expect big changes soon. Virtual reality can add something extra, but the real rollercoaster experience is still the most important part. New technology is exciting, but the physical ride will stay important for a long time.

Miranda Ellington is 25 years old and has done a lot as a choreographer. She makes dances for many theatres and dance companies. Sometimes, she still dances herself. She says dancing helps her remember what it feels like to follow orders from choreographers, which can be hard and stressful. As a choreographer, she teaches and likes working with young students. New dancers are open to trying new things and taking risks. They want to succeed but don't always know their strengths and weaknesses. They listen to feedback, even if it's tough, and sometimes they give her honest feedback too.

When Miranda works with a new group, she focuses on dance steps, and the music guides her. Even if she doesn't like a piece of music, she tries to create the best dance for it. If dancers don't like the music, it can be frustrating, but she has to find solutions. She can't change the music because it's already chosen for big productions. She wishes she could try different music to make rehearsals more fun.

Miranda doesn't want to work with just one theatre or school. She thinks it's important to meet new people and adapt to different styles. This helps her stay flexible and not get stuck in one way of working.

Recently, there was a documentary about ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says it shows the real life of a dance company. One scene shows a young dancer getting many corrections, which is common. The public often doesn't understand how much work ballet requires.

I asked Miranda what makes a great dance show. She says it's when everything like music, costumes, lighting, and dancers come together. Even if not everything is perfect, aiming high is important. Sometimes, good dance steps can be ruined by bad costumes or props.

Miranda has done many different types of work. People want to label her as a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist, but she doesn't like that. She wants to explore many areas and not focus on just one thing. For now, she wants to keep learning and trying new things.

Text: 'A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on TV. I agreed that TV shows amazing things, but why stay at home when there is so much to see and do? This conversation gave me the idea for my fun four-day trip and a film to make people turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the star of the film. I put three wheels and some cables on it and used old seatbelts to hold it. I put my bags on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even one night on the beach. Some friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to keep going. I have been on many walking trips before, but this was different. It was the longest I have ever walked, and it was on main roads. This meant I could stop at a café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of eating sandwiches on a rock. I often told people, “No, I’m not doing it for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks me about my weekend, I like to say how I pulled a sofa 100 miles across southern England instead of talking about the latest TV show. You can see the film on my website.'

When I read about swimming trips in the sea around small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be good for me. At the Greek port, the man was surprised when I asked for one ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I told him I would join ten others to swim around the islands. He still looked confused but smiled and let me on the ferry. Our group had sent emails before the trip, but we didn't have much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides told us a support boat would be with us, and they showed us how to talk to it. We did a short swim to divide into speed groups, then we started our first 1.5 km swim. I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swam in a river, but never in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first swim, and I was happy when I did it by myself. The next days were the same: jumping in, swimming at a good speed, and stopping to look at the scenery. As the swims got longer, I got faster and enjoyed them more. We didn't need the support boat much. I can't wait to come again next year.

Being a flight attendant is not easy, but I love it. Since I started, I have traveled to many places, like the US and Australia. I work with great people, have a lot of free time, and my life is never boring. This job is perfect for a young person like me!

When I was a child, I went to a school in another country, away from my family. I flew alone when school started and ended. I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help give out meals to passengers. Some of them let me help. I remembered this when I wanted to leave my banking job and try something new.

At the interview for the flight attendant job, there were many young people. Many of them were like me, changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I talked about my strengths and my past work experience, not just that I loved to travel. I got the job!

I recommend this job to anyone. There are many good things about it, but free flights are not the best part. Airline staff work very hard, and we have a saying: "No one’s finished till everyone’s finished." We are like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close.

When I am not working, I don’t have to think about work. If I have difficult passengers, which doesn’t happen often, I know the flight will end soon, and I won’t see them again.

At the summer camp where I work, I love seeing the children do things they never thought they could do. Most children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel scared, but after we encourage them, they try it and reach the top. This makes them feel very happy. 

Some children miss home at the start of the week. It's not the very young ones who miss home the most; it's usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we say they can call home after lunch. Then, when they ask again after dinner, we say it's too late now, call tomorrow. Most children feel okay after a few days, and at the end of the week, they thank us because they had a great time.

Sometimes, it's not just the children who feel lonely. Some parents call a lot to ask how their child is doing, which is not needed. Often, the child is busy playing games or doing other activities, so we tell the parents to call back later. We also have some children who come in expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where actors also play music. It started in London last year after being in the USA for five years. In the USA, it won ‘Best Musical’ four times! In the UK, it was hard to do the show with only British actors. In the UK, young actors can do fewer shows each week than in the USA. So, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. The director found many talented actors in the UK, and they won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it is full every night. People want to hear the songs that were first popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s great that I get paid to play, especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He told me the young actors are busy. ‘We have school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ What do his friends think of the show? ‘My whole class came! The theatre has special ticket prices for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he said. When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found another guitar and asked me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days. I didn’t know it, but Jamie helped me, and I was happy when I got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! The young actors were already musicians, and some play many instruments, but none had played in a band before. They found it easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first played together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is really worth seeing.'
